docs.title: Rust Crate for the esphome Native API
docs.text: Implementation of the esphome native API for Rust.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
For simplue usage, you can add the crate to your Cargo.toml:

cargo add esphome-native-api

Have a look at the examples on how to use it.

docs.title: Only proto definitions
docs.text:
If you only want the to use the proto definitions (alrady no_std conform), you target the feature flag with the specific version you want to use: 

cargo add esphome-native-api --features "version_2025_7_3"

docs.title: Roadmap
docs.text:
• Fully no_std compatible
  • "Easy" server which abstracts some of the complexity of the API

docs.title: Encryption
docs.text:
Recently Added by the ESPHome Team: https://developers.esphome.io/architecture/api/protocol_details/

It uses the Noise Protocol Framework, specifically the Noise_NNpsk0_25519_ChaChaPoly_SHA256 pattern.

The Encryption protocol is reusing the base frame format and the packet format (although encrypted). But some parts are predetermined instead of variable:

  • No VarInt Length, the length is always 2 bytes (an unsigned 16-bit integer in big-endian format).
---
title: "Example Frame"
config:
  packet:
    bitsPerRow: 8
    bitWidth: 128
---
packet-beta
  0: "Preamble"
  1-2: "Length"
  3-7: "Data"
Part Bits Description Example Preamble 1 Marker bit which states if unencrypted (0x00) or encrypted (0x01) 0x00 Length 2 Length of the Data (an unsigned 16-bit integer in big-endian format) 0x0016 or 0x0001 Data 0-16,383 Encrypted or unencrypted Packet

docs.title: Initialization of the encryption protocol
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    Client->>Server: HandshakeHello *Zero Byte encrypted*
    Server->>Client: Custom Server Hello
    Client->>Server: HandshakeRequest *Zero Byte encrypted*
    Server->>Client: HandshakeResponse *Zero Byte encrypted*

    loop Normal Messaging
        Client->>Server: PingRequest
        Server->>Client: PingResponse
    end

  1. Client Sends (both at once for some reason)

  2. NoiseHello: \x01\x00\x00 (a zero byte message with the encryption preamble set)

  3. HandshakeRequest is send by the client (which is just a zero byte encrypted message)

  4. The Server responds with a Custom Server Hello message:

---
title: "Custom Server Hello"
config:
  packet:
    bitsPerRow: 8
    bitWidth: 100
---
packet-beta
  0-0: "Preamble (0x01)"
  1-2: "Length"
  3-7: "Server Name (Variable Length)"
  8: "Delimiter (0x00)"
  9-15: "Mac Address (Variable Length)"
  16: "Delimiter (0x00)"
Part Bits Description Example Preamble 1 Marker bit which states if unencrypted (0x00) or encrypted (0x01) 0x00 Length 1-2 Length of the Data (an unsigned 16-bit integer in big-endian format) 0x16 or 0xFFFFFFFFFF Server Name 3-X Name of the Server test_server Delimiter X + 1 Zero Byte Delimiter 0x00 Mac Address X + 2 - Y Mac Address of the Server 00:11:22:33:44:55 Delimiter Y + 1 Zero Byte Delimiter 0x00
  1. It then send a Handshake Response, which is also a zero byte encrypted message.
  2. Normal protocol messaging begins (e.g. HelloRequest).

Notes:

  • for api encryption the mdns entry needs to be added: "api_encryption=Noise_NNpsk0_25519_ChaChaPoly_SHA256"

docs.title: Client connects without encryption
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    Client->>Server: HelloRequest
    Server->>Client: HelloResponse (with encryption preamble set)
  1. HelloRequest is sent by the client.
  2. The Server responds with a HelloResponse with the encryption preamble set to 0x01 (indicating that the server requires encryption).
  3. Connection is closed by the server.

docs.title: Client connects with wrong encryption key
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    Client->>Server: HandshakeRequest *Zero Byte encrypted*
    Server->>Client: Custom Server Hello
    Server->>Client: HandshakeResponse (with error message)
  1. HelloRequest is sent by the client.
  2. The Server responds with a Custom Server Hello message (see above).
  3. The Server responds with a HandshakeResponse with an error message
  4. The connection is closed by the server.
---
title: "HandshakeResponse"
config:
  packet:
    bitsPerRow: 8
    bitWidth: 100
---
packet-beta
  0-0: "Preamble (0x01)"
  1-2: "Length"
  3-3: "Status"
  4-31: "(Encrypted) Message"
Part Bits Description Example Preamble 1 Marker bit which states if unencrypted (0x00) or encrypted (0x01) 0x00 Length 1-2 Length of the Data (an unsigned 16-bit integer in big-endian format) 0x16 or 0xFFFFFFFFFF Status 3 Status of the Handshake (0x00 = Success, 0x01 = Failure) 0x00 (Encrypted) Message 4-X If the Status indicates success the message will be an encrypted zero byte array. If the Status indicates a Failure it contains an unencrypted utf-8 encoded error message. 0x00

docs.title: General
docs.text: The messaging protocol is based on protobuf messages. There is no signaling for switching between encrypted and unencrypted communication.

docs.title: Frame Format <sup>1</sup>
docs.text:
---
title: "Example Frame"
config:
  packet:
    bitsPerRow: 8
    bitWidth: 128
---
packet-beta
  0: "Preamble"
  1: "Length"
  2-7: "Data"
Part Bits Description Example Preamble 1 Marker bit which states if unencrypted (0x00) or encrypted (0x01) 0x00 Length 1-5 Variable Message Length according to VarInt Specification (encrypted frames ignore the spec and always use 2 bytes) 0x16 or 0xFFFFFFFFFF Data 0-34,359,738,367 Encrypted or unencrypted Packet

Attention: Unencrypted Frames Length is calculated without the Packet type byte!

docs.title: Packet
docs.text:
---
title: "Example Packet"
---
packet-beta
  0-1: "Type"
  2-31: "Message"
Part Description Example Type Internal number for identifying the proto message => Link to custom mapping 0x01 (HelloMessage) Message Content

docs.title: Example Communication
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    Client->>Api: HelloRequest
    Api->>Client: HelloResponse
    Client->>Api: DisconnectRequest


    Client->>Api: ConnectRequest
    Api->>Client: ConnectResponse
    Client->>Api: DeviceInfoRequest
    Api->>Client: DeviceInfoResponse
    Client->>+Api: ListEntitiesRequest
    Api->>Client: ListEntitiesSensorResponse
    Api->>Client: ListEntitiesBinarySensorResponse
    Api->>-Client: ListEntitiesDoneResponse

    loop Keep Alive Messaging
        Client->>Api: PingRequest
        Api->>Client: PingResponse
    end

    Client->>Api: DisconnectRequest
    Api->>Client: DisconnectResponse

docs.title: Unencrypted to Encrypted Handover
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    Client->>Api: HelloRequest (unencrypted)
    Api->>Client: DisconnectResponse (encrypted)

    Client->>Api: HelloRequest (encrypted)
    Api->>Client: HelloResponse (encrypted)
    %% ...
